newsitem.title: INDIA: India urged to remove duty on internet equipment.
newsitem.headline: India urged to remove duty on internet equipment.

text.p: The Indian government should have no tariff on internet related computer equipment, and the cost of leased cicuits should be reduced, a senior offficial of computer maker Silicon Graphics Systems India (SGSI) said on Tuesday.

"Reductions in these tariffs will offer consumers a viable business tool that will increase efficiency and cost," said Ashok Desai, managing director SAARC, SGSI, a unit of Silicon Graphics Inc, at a technology conference organised by the Indo-American Chamber of Commerce (AICC).
Desai said current rates were amongst the highest in the world and added to the cost of doing business, thereby invalidating the core strength of this technology.
The import duty on computers in India is 37.86 per cent, and the annual cost of a 64 kilobits per second leased circuit is 1.5 million rupees ($41,900).
Desai said the Indian Telegraph Act needed to be amended as it did not allow networks that use encrypted data on regular phone lines, which hindered the setting up of intranets.
"All these steps, if implemented, would promote electronic commerce, accelerate the pace of business and lead to employment generation," he said.
He added that the effective use of web technology had helped companies all over the world to expand their businesses in ways that were not possible earlier.
"We believe that India has the requisite software expertise to enable us to attain world leadership in this emerging field," Desai said. ($1 = 35.8 rupees)
